the regular chords (especially in the chorus) and a variation in the last 
verse (an extra Dm/A).

I also added tabs for verse, chorus and the two bar link which features 
a Bb (the minor 7th of the C chord) in the bass that is also missing 
from the other versions but which adds to the gospel feel of the song.

The final track from "The Lamb Lies Down on Broadway". And the best one, in my 
opionion, a superb ending to any set. Not 100% accurate, but every note in 
Hackett's lead guitar lines and Gabriel's vocals can be played correctly with this setup.

Intro/Chorus

It repeats this "verse-chorus" strcture three complete times without really 
containing a chorus at all. For the end, just repeat the | [ch]Cmaj7[/ch] [ch]Bm7[/ch] | pattern 
until satisfied.

Here are the chords for the song (tabbed out), keep in mind that I fingerpick 
everything I play, so my chords may be different than the ones flat pickers 
commonly use. Just mute the x'd strings or don't play them at all.

Hey everyone I'm not sure if this is completely like the original but of the 
versions i've tried on this site i think this sounds the best! I realize it is not 
in the original key but that can be adjusted by starting with capo 4 or simply 
transpose up 3 half steps. The key this is in works very well for female vocals, 
especially soprano. 

Since the key change can have some tricky chords, I did rate this as an 
intermediate level tab. However, you can get around this by moving the capo up a 
fret in the rest between "you are, you are, you are, you are..." and "don't wanna 
hear you say" and continue with the previous chords.

content.text:
------------------------------------------------------------------
                      Overview (Please Read)
------------------------------------------------------------------
This is an acoustic guitar arrangement for the song Let It Go, from Disney's Frozen. 
This arrangement was made because of the difficulty of transposing an orchestral 
score to acoustic guitar, and combines parts unique to the soundtrack version with
parts unique to the single (Demi Lovato) version. Some chords had to be changed 
because the two versions are in different keys. This arrangement uses the original
soundtrack key of A flat major (starting in the relative minor). Like most songs 
that use a capo, these chords are transcribed by the chord shape, not the chord sound.
That is, despite fingering a G chord, you're actually play Ab.

------------------------------------------------------------------
---------------------------PLEASE NOTE----------------------------
-   This arrangement is different then any recorded versions     -
-                    and is intended to be                       -
-          Please do not comment about any inaccuracies          -
-              compared to either recorded versions              -      
------------------------------------------------------------------

------------------------------------------------------------------
                         Chords and Tuning
------------------------------------------------------------------
Key of Ab Major

Standard Tuning
Capo on 1

Chord Shapes

[ch]G[/ch] (320033)
[ch]D[/ch] (xx0232)
[ch]Dadd11/F#[/ch] (200233)
[ch]C[/ch] (x32010
[ch]Cadd9[/ch] (x32033)
[ch]Em[/ch] (022000)
[ch]Em7[/ch] (022033)
[ch]A[/ch] (x02220)
[ch]Am[/ch] (x02210)
[ch]Asus4[/ch] (x02230)
[ch]G/B[/ch]  (x20033)

[ch]Cadd2[/ch] (x32030)

[Bridge 2]**

[ch]C[/ch]

Let the storm rage on        
[ch]C[/ch]
The cold never bothered me anyway



------------------------------------------------------------------
                              Notes
------------------------------------------------------------------

*The break is just two measures, play it the same way you'd play the first 
line of the chorus, but where the second line of the chorus would start, 
begin the second verse. It takes some practice to get the timing right, 
but it should sync up with the recorded Idina Menzel version still at that 
point, so you can listen to it for timing. It's when the orchestral strings 
come in.

**The first three lines of the second bridge (which is the second half of 
the bridge from the original recording) sound better with power chords or
5 chords. The fingerings for these are: C (x355xx) and D (x577xx). 
Additionally, this arrangement is structured in a way that you could drop 
the entire second bridge, if you so choose, but it adds tension and 
complexity to the final third of the song.

Finally, in almost the entire song the Dadd11/F# chord can either be replaced 
by a normal D chord (Chorus) or a Dsus4 chord (all other times). The fingering
is: Dsus4 (xx0233).
